FY-THRIVE.name: College Thriving
outcomes: Increase and appreciate the significance of self-awareness
Value a liberal arts education
Develop goal-setting and reflection skills using metacognition and self-regulated learning
Describe academic strategies, policies, and pathways and their link to resources
Reflect on components of thriving including positive emotion, engagement, meaning, and resilience
Master mental health, substance use, and sexual wellness fundamentals

FY-WRITING.name: Writing at the Research University
outcomes: Employ conventions, genres, and rhetoric practiced in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities
Conduct research using a variety of methods, databases, and sources
Discuss and present research-based arguments and information
Identify discipline-specific approaches to using research and evidence
Compose using written, oral, and multimedia modes
Review and revise one's own work and assist others in revising their work

FY-SEMINAR.name: First-Year Seminar
outcomes: Establish early faculty connections in educational journey
Learn intensively among a small cohort of students
Apply disciplinary methods for posing problems and evaluating knowledge
Produce knowledge through self-directed inquiry and active learning

FY-LAUNCH.name: First-Year Launch
outcomes: Establish early faculty connections in educational journey
Learn intensively among a small cohort of students
Understand foundational discipline concepts
Analyze and communicate broad introductory topics

FY-DATA.name: Data Literacy Lab
outcomes: Demonstrate understanding of the essentials of computer architecture and data security
Recognize how data is collected, manipulated, and accessed
Interpret analyzed data to make meaningful conclusions
Identify the ethical challenges that arise when working with data and their impact on society

GLBL-LANG.name: Global Language
outcomes: Communicate orally and in writing in a foreign language across varied situations and audiences
Demonstrate comprehension of oral and written texts in a foreign language on a wide range of topics
Apply perspectives, practices, and ideas associated with the culture(s) of a foreign language

FC-AESTH.name: Aesthetic and Interpretive Analysis
outcomes: Interpret and critique literary and artistic expression
Analyze literary and artistic works in various contexts (social, political, historical, philosophical, etc.)
Explain how aesthetic expression enhances human experience

FC-CREATE.name: Creative Expression, Practice, and Production
outcomes: Compose, design, build, present, or perform a work that is the result of immersion in a creative process
Explain the roles and influences of creativity, technologies, materials, and design processes
Evaluate their own and others' creative work to demonstrate how critique creates value

FC-PAST.name: Engagement with the Human Past
outcomes: Develop knowledge of different spatiotemporal scales, patterns, ideas, figures, and events from the past
Evaluate primary source material and/or other historical evidence of past conditions
Assess conflicting historical narratives based on evidence and methodologies
Generate and evaluate arguments based on the analysis of primary and scholarly sources
Apply historical methods and knowledge to make informed judgments about the past and the present

FC-VALUES.name: Ethical and Civic Values
outcomes: Explain the contexts in which questions of justification arise
Assess ethical values in terms of reasons offered
Recognize different ethical perspectives and the distinctive approaches these perspectives bring to questions of value
Analyze the differences between personal ethical decisions and those bearing on the public and civic spheres

FC-GLOBAL.name: Global Understanding and Engagement
outcomes: Classify and analyze diverse historical, social, and political exchanges that shape nations, regions, and cultural traditions
Translate among contrasting civic cultures, social values, and moral commitments that characterize differences among peoples
Assess ways that political and economic institutions shape contemporary global relations
Explain human and environmental challenges that transcend national borders

FC-NATSCI.name: Natural Scientific Investigation
outcomes: Demonstrate the ability to use scientific knowledge, logic, and imagination to construct and justify scientific claims
Analyze and apply processes of scientific inquiry as dictated by the phenomena and questions at hand
Evaluate science-related claims and information from popular and/or peer-reviewed sources
Identify, assess, and make informed decisions about ethical issues at the intersections of the natural sciences and society

FC-POWER.name: Power and Society
outcomes: Analyze configurations of social, economic, and political power and how they influence the functioning of societies
Examine how the organization of social, economic, and political systems affects the distribution of resources, opportunities, and influence
Interrogate the processes by which such systems are established, sustained, and at times challenged and changed

FC-QUANT.name: Quantitative Reasoning
outcomes: Summarize, interpret, and present quantitative data in mathematical forms, such as graphs, diagrams, tables, or mathematical text
Develop or compute representations of data using mathematical forms or equations as models
Make and evaluate important assumptions in the estimation, modeling, and analysis of data
Apply mathematical concepts, data, procedures, and solutions to make judgments and draw conclusions
Synthesize and present quantitative data to others to explain findings or to provide quantitative evidence

FC-KNOWING.name: Ways of Knowing
outcomes: Recognize and use one or more approach(es) to developing and validating knowledge of the unfamiliar world
Evaluate ways that temporal, spatial, scientific, and philosophical categories structure knowledge
Interrogate assumptions that underlie our own perceptions of the world
Employ strategies to mitigate or adjust for preconceptions and biases
Apply critical insights to understand patterns of experience and belief

FC-LAB.name: Empirical Investigation Lab
outcomes: Take empirical measurements using appropriate apparatus
Generate and test hypotheses
Gather, store, and organize data
Analyze and report on data and hypothesis testing

RESEARCH.name: Research and Discovery
outcomes: Frame a topic, develop an original research question or creative goal, and establish a point of view, creative approach, or hypothesis
Obtain a procedural understanding of how conclusions can be reached in a field and gather appropriate evidence
Evaluate the quality of the arguments and/or evidence in support of the emerging product
Communicate findings in clear and compelling ways
Critique and identify the limits of the conclusions of the project and generate ideas for future work

HIGH-IMPACT.name: High-Impact Experience
outcomes: Explain the connections between academic studies and outside-the-classroom experiences and observations
Apply knowledge in complex or ambiguous situations
Develop questions from experiences and observations to deepen and extend academic inquiry

COMMBEYOND.name: Communication Beyond Carolina
outcomes: Ascertain the expectations, opportunities, and barriers to oral communication in distinct situations
Tailor oral communications to different kinds of settings, including individual, small group, and public communication
Tailor oral communications to different levels of expertise and varying levels of alignment with distinct contexts
Make informed situation- and audience-sensitive strategic choices in content and delivery
Improve ability to move audiences, as measured by best practices, audience feedback, and instructor feedback

INTERDISC.name: Interdisciplinary
outcomes: Compare and contrast the questions and methods multiple disciplines might use to gain a more complete understanding
Explain how an interdisciplinary approach changes our ability to solve problems and form understandings of complex topics
Synthesize knowledge and processes from multiple disciplines to solve problems and/or generate new ideas

LIFE-FIT.name: Lifetime Fitness
outcomes: Engage in healthy physical activity and nutritional behaviors
Assess your own physical activity and fitness
Design and initiate a personal physical activity plan for aerobic and muscular fitness
Create solutions for overcoming barriers to maintaining lifetime fitness and proper nutrition throughout life

CAMPUS-LIFE.name: Campus Life Experience
outcomes: Attend a diverse set of campus performances, lectures, and events
Interpret performances, lectures, and events in light of academic study
Participate in the life of a university campus and its activities outside the classroom

AMER-DEM.name: Foundations of American Democracy
outcomes: Identify and analyze the political, historical, and cultural impact of founding documents on governance and democracy in America
Identify and analyze the political, historical, and cultural impact of key milestones in American history on the evolution of democratic republicanism
Evaluate key concepts, principles, arguments and contexts in founding documents of the American republic
Evaluate key milestones in progress and challenges in the effort to form 'a more perfect Union'
